forecast.rationale:
- Evidence and context: Per the assistant’s research, Metz pleaded not guilty to felony charges after allegedly shooting a 17-year-old in the face while the teen sat in a car outside Metz’s home; law enforcement has said there was no indication of criminal intent by the teen. Metz took a leave of absence. Local coverage is highly salient and negative. The recall election is scheduled for May 20, 2025.
- Base rates: Municipal recalls that reach the ballot tend to succeed more often than not (roughly a majority, often around the 60–70% range in various datasets), with success rates higher when the triggering incident is a serious scandal. Small-town special elections typically feature low turnout where motivated opposition has an edge.
- Status quo weighting: Nothing in the public narrative has shifted toward exoneration or mitigation; the criminal case is unresolved. The default trajectory is that opponents remain more energized than supporters, making “recall succeeds” the status quo outcome.
- Factors pushing toward No (recall succeeds): Serious, emotive incident involving a teen; negative and ongoing media attention; unresolved felony charges; Metz’s leave of absence signaling reduced capacity; organized opponents already met the signature bar; low-turnout dynamics favor motivated recall voters.
- Factors pushing toward Yes (he retains): Very small electorate means personal networks can matter; some voters may view recall as premature before trial and default to due process; Colorado’s mail-ballot context can boost overall turnout and dampen the anti-incumbent edge if Metz organizes effectively; if trusted local figures or institutions publicly back him, that could sway enough voters.
- Why not higher: The severity and optics of the incident, combined with recall base rates and small-town mobilization dynamics, make retention unlikely absent new exculpatory developments or unusually strong GOTV for Metz.
- Why not lower: Small electorates are volatile; even a few dozen votes could swing the result. If Metz has strong neighborhood-level support, or if ballot return data indicates higher-than-expected turnout from supportive demographics, he could survive.
- What would move me up: Credible local polling showing the recall trailing; visible endorsements from respected local leaders; robust pro-Metz field effort (canvassing/mailers); ballot return stats suggesting high turnout among older or historically pro-incumbent voters; any legal development substantially weakening the case against him.
- What would move me down: Additional negative revelations; victim/family public engagement boosting recall sentiment; endorsements for recall from town leaders; ballot return stats indicating strong anti-incumbent precincts turning out disproportionately.
